name: Bread Pakora
history: Bread Pakora is a popular Indian snack, a favorite during monsoons and cold weather. It's a deep-fried snack made by coating bread with a spicy gram flour batter.
description: Bread Pakora, also known as Bread Bajji, is a savory snack where slices of bread are dipped in a seasoned gram flour batter and deep-fried until golden and crispy. It's often stuffed with spiced potatoes.

equipment.name: deep frying pan
equipment.description: Used for deep frying the pakoras.

instructions.title: Prepare the Batter
instructions.description: In a mixing bowl, combine gram flour, rice flour, ajwain, red chili powder, turmeric powder, and salt. Gradually add water to make a thick batter.

instructions.title: Dip the Bread
instructions.description: Cut the bread slices into desired shapes. Dip each piece in the batter, ensuring it's well coated.

instructions.title: Fry the Pakoras
instructions.description: Heat oil in a deep frying pan. Carefully slide the batter-coated bread slices into the hot oil. Fry until they turn golden brown and crispy.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the Bread Pakoras hot with green chutney or ketchup.

tips: The consistency of the batter is crucial; it should coat the bread evenly without being too thick or runny.
Maintain a medium heat while frying to avoid burning the pakoras.
variations: For a stuffed version, add a layer of spiced mashed potatoes between two bread slices before dipping in the batter.
Experiment with different herbs and spices in the batter for variety.

storage.shelfLife: Bread Pakoras are best consumed fresh but can be stored for a few hours.
storage.instructions: Keep in an airtight container at room temperature; reheat in an oven or air fryer before serving.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat in an oven or air fryer until crispy.
presentationTips: Garnish with sliced onions and serve on a plate with a side of mint or tamarind chutney.
